reviewText:
I am way more than qualified to tell you....this game is pay to win.

My main was Rewt, some of you might know me.  Cash rules in this game, I quit after many many exploits were exploited by less than honorable users. Despite this, exploiters were given hand slaps.  It became an inside joke in the game that if you discovered an exploit, abuse the hell out of it before anyone found out.

As if you needed another reason, the balance in this game is god awful.  Basically, you have 3 trees per class.  Only one of these is viable in pvp.  That's if you chose a class that's viable in pvp at all.  Set teams rule arena, (I was in one) which is like queue, accept, cast 5 spells, battle over in 1 min.

What ruined this game?  The cash shop.  You can spend up to what your cc can stand.  Pure straight up CC to power. Several people have spent over $100K USD. No, that's not a typo.

I would be remiss to not point out that the game is beautiful.  It does have it's strengths.  If you don't pvp, the dungeons can be fun.  There's not raids as such, and don't take forever.  It's quick fun runs, they did that right.  There are dailies, but not onerous.

If you don't have 10K lying around, getting into this game at this late date, you'll never be good at pvp.  If you just like beautiful games and exploring, give it a try.

Oh, and the global chat is NSFW and not safe for children, thought I should mention that.

reviewText:
I played the game probably way longer than I should have, Steam records over 1000 hours which doesn't even include the time when I wasn't playing on Steam.

It started out pretty good for me. Early levels aren't too bad, and a lot of the dungeon mechanics are actually very interesting and fun.

By the time I stopped playing, game development had been going in an increasingly bad direction. Things were becoming increasingly and ridiculously grindy. I suppose in some recognition that it was too grindy, they implemented a bot system that would control your character in a limited fashion that helps with some of the more mundane grinding.

At some point, even with sinking ridiculous hours into the game, it's nearly impossible to be competitive without cash shop purchases. Dungeons start to become gear-gated. Many of what were once challenging dungeon mechanics become trivial once you hit a gear threshold. And you end up running these dungeons a ton of times because of how grindy the game is, and it really becomes a chore.

Both in PvP and PvE, class balance doesn't seem to be handled very well, which becomes increasingly clear the farther you progress. This may have been fixed in the meantime, but was one of the main reasons (along with client instability and the absurd amount of grinding) that I stopped playing. I was playing one of the two classes that were considered basically unviable in PvP (Protector and Marksman).

On the plus side, I've heard good things about large scale PvP and inter-server PvP have been added as well, but it's not enough to make me come back to what I feel is a broken game.

This is a lovable MMOrpg where your first objective should be to join one of the many guilds in the game. Preferably you should also choose one of the more crowded servers. From Europe? go Illyfue. The US? Lionhart. Anyhow, this MMO is special compared to the many others I've played, since It has several pretty fun Daily and Weekly event, a decent amount of instances you can run and even a even where you wage war against other guilds for territories. The downside to the game being, the lower levels are not as fun. You'll have to preferably be lvl 75 and higher to enjoy most of the most fun event that this game has to offer. As a guildleader in this game I often see players eagerly joining the game just to quit 3-4 days later. So you gotta really step up your early game!

Well, besides lots of pretty neat event going on. This is a very nice game for when you have achived max lvl, since there are always upgrades to do for your Avatar, whether it be getting the best PVE or PVP gear, fortifying gear to the max (harder than it sounds) or increasing your resistances for that extra PVP durability. Well, to new players this most probably sounds like a heap of gibberish.

Now the last part I wanted to mention, which ofcourse makes the game more fun but can be annoying for regular players. Are the people who CS (cash shop for real money). With CS'ing you get the option of for example Marrying someone in the game including marriage quests, various amounts of fashion to make your character look nice, pets, mounts and Orb (basically open them to randomly get lesser rewards - epic rewards depending on your luck).

Luckily most of these things can be achived by buying them from the ingame auction house.

In the end I would definitly recommend this game, since it means a lot to me and has brought me tons of enjoyable moments, more than any other MMO so far. Heck I even met my current Girlfriend in this game. To me this is more than a game, it's become a part of my life. Also I usually play on Arc another substitute to steam. See the Hours on record?
91 Days 21 hours + those few 125 hours. If that doesn't convince ya idk.

Anyhow have a good one and ty for reading this far xD ~Zeroshira

I've wasted way too much on this grind fest. Don't bother.

I'll elaborate, I played this back in closed beta, then when it released into open beta/full release, I put insurmountable hours into this game (well before it showed up on steam) and all I really got out of it was nothing really.

I played so much I and some friends started a guild, I was leader and we quickly grew pretty large. Now at this point I should explain at the beginning a guild was basically just a group, but as they released updates, the pain began. As it is with all Asian theme-park mmo's it eventually devolves into a grind-fest, this game follows that same principal, unless you join a guild, or decide to create a guild with friends. You will find yourself trapped in a never ending cycle of dailies, and it's pretty much all for the guild especially if you're the leader. If you're not running the guild you can still find fun in the time you spend in the game, but overall it's not exactly the best game out there, there is a lot lacking in terms of what you would want to do, like some races have bizarre choices to them, I am 100% aware that it's Asian and should not be surprised to see chibi animoo style characters, and I'm not, it's bizarre that they made stonemen, but no stonewomen, like why not? who cares? it would be cool to have. But seriously, dwarf females look ridiculous compared to dwarf males, like, what even.

Aside from that, the story isn't great pretty generic, but again no one is really paying attention to the story in this game, I knew way too many people who just skipped through all the dialog cause they didn't care.

Game play was okay it's the standard stand still and hammer on your skill shortcuts till you win. You have mounts some that run and some that fly, neither are really impressive.
Different races/classes play interestingly enough, I felt that the bard class was pretty interesting in how it played, basically tying together chords to make melodies which attack or buff or whatever, werewolves were a cool concept baring in mind they are also enemies in the game, and you are basically stuck with another humanoid character, but you can become a werewolf... for about 5 seconds and then it cools down before you can do it again.

There is obviously a shop where you can buy stuff with RL money, and it's alright no p2w stuff from what I remember, a lot of price gouging though, all that ♥♥♥♥ you're buying costs way more than it's worth, but then that perfect world entertainment.

TL/DR;

It's okay but also not okay, the game can be fun if you're into Asian theme park mmo's and you avoid being a guild leader, seriously do not try to run a guild unless you want this to be less fun and more work or you enjoy doing dailies forever and like dealing with nonsensical drama all day.

You can try it if you feel like it's worth it, I would recommend against it, for me it's just not worth it.

Oh, I will give it props where deserved, At least they made their western fantasy themed mmo with mostly western fantasy themed designs, like for instance you can make elves and humans that look like fantasy elves and western fantasy style humans, also dwarves aren't just short people (except for the female dwarves), this is a pretty good move on their part especially considering other games touting a western fantasy theme (*cough*Archeage*cough*) and you get a cast of weirdly designed asian style characters running around in a western fantasy designed world.

Anyway, I still say stay away, unless you got all the time in the world for this.

reviewText: Steam now supports F2P games. Among them Forsaken World, a game from the creators of Perfect World and other free Chinese MMOs. Forsaken World is their most recent game and offers content that is similar to World of Warcraft while maintaining its own identity. There are eight classes scattered across five races, each of which fills the usual roles of either tank, healer or DPS. Nagivation is very easy due to the click-to-move way of nagivation. Quests have hypertext which can make your character move to precisely where you need to go. This means you spend less time getting lost in the huge terrain, and more time killing bad guys, completing quests and whatnot. A free for all PVP system also is quite refreshing for those used to faction based PVP on other games. Most surpriseing however is not only how beautiful the game is, but also how solid its translation is. Overall, Forsaken World is a very enjoyable game and a good alternative for medieval fantasy MMO if you're sick of WoW.

I've clocked a few hours on it after downloading from the company website, and I'm pretty sure the Steam version is faster.  It could just be server updates that make it run faster than before.  Whatever the case, this game is for a niche market, and that niche is occasional gamers.  Not casual, occasional.  Want to level by grinding? The one thing an MMO has to get right is controls. If the controls are bad, no one is going to want to sink 100's of hours into the game.

The game defaults to both keyboard movement and click-to-move. Ask what the player wants up front and provide a better control scheme for the chosen option.
Even with click-to-move off, left clicking will auto-move to clicked targets.
Left click dragging does not rotate the camera.
Right click does not activate auto-attack, instead it must be used as an action button.
You cannot move during auto-attacks. The auto-attack animation will be interrupted and no damage will go through.
Collision is all sorts of messed up. Something you should easily be able to jump over has collision and prevents you from jumping over it. They expect everyone to just use the auto-pathing.
Auto-pathing uses a sequential waypoint system. Did you go past a waypoint? Better backtrack so that you can stand directly over the waypoint before proceeding. Could you get to your destination by going straight? Well the laid out waypoints weren't designed for that path, so you better go get on the prebuilt waypoint way off to the side and take a more conviluted path.
Additionally, the game does not let you scale the UI. If you have a large resolution, 1440p+, expect to not be able to use your minimap.
